content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are willing to take risks and are fairly comfortable with uncertainty. You tend to embrace new opportunities even if they involve some risk. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my risk-taking nature and comfort with uncertainty, I would choose to play this game strategically rather than randomly. In such games, it's often beneficial to adopt a strategy that guarantees a minimal outcome while maximizing potential gains.

In this case, if both players always pick R, they each earn 45$ per round for 75 rounds, totaling 3150$. If either player deviates and chooses B even once, the other player will get 35$, but the deviating player will lose out on a potential 45$. Since there are 75 rounds, the most the opponent can gain by deviating is 75*.35 = 26.25$ (assuming they always choose B after their first deviation).

On the other hand, if both players choose R, they will earn a total of 3150$. However, if the opponent chooses R for the first few rounds and then switches to B, the player who stuck with R can still gain 697.5$ (75*.40 - 26.25).

Given this analysis, it seems that choosing R and hoping my opponent will also choose R for the majority of the game could result in a higher payoff. However, since the opponent is anonymous, I can't be certain of their strategy. Therefore, I might consider adopting a mixed strategy, where I randomly switch between R and B to increase the likelihood that my opponent doesn't profit from deviating.

Ultimately, given my risk-seeking personality, I would choose to play R for the first few rounds to maximize potential gains while keeping in mind the possibility of adopting a mixed strategy if needed. I will make my choice as follows: {R}
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

Now that I have seen my opponent choose R, I will continue with my strategy of initially choosing R to maximize potential gains. However, since my opponent has already chosen R, there's no benefit in continuing to do so for every round. To maintain a balanced and unpredictable approach, I will adopt a mixed strategy by randomly switching between R and B in future rounds.

You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 35$. Please play the next round.

In this case, I chose R when my opponent chose B, resulting in a 0$ payout for me and a 35$ payout for my opponent. Given that I have lost out on a potential 45$, it would be irrational to continue with the same strategy of always choosing R. To avoid such losses in future rounds, I will switch my strategy to choosing B whenever my opponent chooses R.
